title-group.subtitle: A Program for Determining Sample Sizes for Testing and Estimating Coefficient Alpha and for Comparing Two Alpha Coefficients

article-meta.aff: 1University of Nevada, Las Vegas, Nevada, USA

author-notes.corresp: N. Clayton Silver, 4505 Maryland Pkwy, Las Vegas, NV 89154-5030, USA Email: fdnsilvr@unlv.nevada.edu

body.p: Coefficient alpha is one of the most widely reported measures of internal consistency. Although there have been hypothesis tests developed for coefficient alpha (e.g., Feldt, Woodruff, & Salih, 1987), the researcher might first consider estimating sample size for determining statistical significance. Sample-size formulas for testing the hypothesis that the sample coefficient alpha differs from the theoretical coefficient alpha with a given power and for estimating coefficient alpha with a specified precision were developed by Bonett (2002). Furthermore, he also derived a sample-size formula for testing the difference between alpha coefficients for specific values of power (Bonett, 2003). Therefore, the purpose of the user-friendly, stand-alone program was to compute the estimated sample sizes for aiding researchers in planning their study.

sec.title: Description
sec.p: The user is queried interactively to estimate sample size for the following: (a) a specified precision for coefficient alpha, (b) testing the difference between the sample and population coefficient alphas, or (c) testing the difference between two coefficient alphas. The user inputs the number of items, the coefficient alpha(s), the confidence interval probability (e.g., .95), power (for testing hypotheses), and specified precision (for estimating coefficient alpha). The program, using the algorithm by Wichura (1988) for computing the percentage points of the normal distribution, responds with a restatement of the input variables along with sample-size estimates and hypothetical confidence intervals where applicable. The program is written in FORTRAN 77 and runs on any IBM-PC or compatible. The output is contained in SAMPAL.OUT.

sec.title: Availability
sec.p: SAMPAL.FOR and the executable version (SAMPAL.EXE) may be obtained at no charge by sending an email request to N. Clayton Silver, Department of Psychology, University of Nevada at Las Vegas, Las Vegas, NV 89154-5030 or at fdnsilvr@unlv.nevada.edu.
